title: Modeling a Non-Periodic Context-Exponential Function, Part B

content.question: Part B (i) Use the given data to find the average rate of change of the number of fish that migrated up the river, in fish per year, from <math alttext="t equals 0"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> to <math alttext="t equals 6"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> years. Express your answer as a decimal approximation. Show the computations that lead to your answer. (ii) Use the average rate of change found in (i) to estimate the number of fish that migrated up the river in 2017 (<math alttext="t equals 2"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>). Show the work that leads to your answer. (iii) Let <math alttext="A subscript t"><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>t</mi></msub></math> represent the estimate of the number of fish that migrated up the river using the average rate of change found in (i). For <math alttext="A subscript 2"><msub><mi>A</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, found in (ii), it can be shown that <math alttext="A subscript 2 greater than F open parentheses 2 close parentheses"><msub><mi>A</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi>F</mi><mfenced><mn>2</mn></mfenced></math>. Explain why, in general, <math alttext="A subscript t greater than F open parentheses t close parentheses"> <msub> <mi>A</mi> <mi>t</mi> </msub> <mo>></mo> <mi>F</mi> <mfenced> <mi>t</mi> </mfenced> </math> for all <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>, where <math alttext="0 less than t less than 6"><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.

frqParts.text: Part B (i) Use the given data to find the average rate of change of the number of fish that migrated up the river, in fish per year, from <math alttext="t equals 0"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> to <math alttext="t equals 6"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> years. Express your answer as a decimal approximation. Show the computations that lead to your answer. (ii) Use the average rate of change found in (i) to estimate the number of fish that migrated up the river in 2017 (<math alttext="t equals 2"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>). Show the work that leads to your answer. (iii) Let <math alttext="A subscript t"><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>t</mi></msub></math> represent the estimate of the number of fish that migrated up the river using the average rate of change found in (i). For <math alttext="A subscript 2"><msub><mi>A</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, found in (ii), it can be shown that <math alttext="A subscript 2 greater than F open parentheses 2 close parentheses"><msub><mi>A</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi>F</mi><mfenced><mn>2</mn></mfenced></math>. Explain why, in general, <math alttext="A subscript t greater than F open parentheses t close parentheses"> <msub> <mi>A</mi> <mi>t</mi> </msub> <mo>></mo> <mi>F</mi> <mfenced> <mi>t</mi> </mfenced> </math> for all <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>, where <math alttext="0 less than t less than 6"><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.

topic.text: 1.3: Rates of Change in Linear and Quadratic Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.B: Express functions, equations, or expressions in analytically equivalent forms that are useful in a given mathematical or applied context.
